{{Infobox Software | name = Almquist shell | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | developer = | latest release version = | latest release date = | programming language = [[C (programming language)|C]] | operating system = [[Cross-platform]] | platform = [[Cross-platform]] | language = English, multilingual ([[gettext]]) | status = Active | genre = [[Unix shell]] | source_model = [[Open source]] | license = | website = {{URL|http://www.in-ulm.de/~mascheck/various/ash/}} }} The '''Almquist shell''' (also known as '''A Shell''', '''ash''' and '''sh''') was originally [[Kenneth Almquist]]'s clone of the [[SVR4]]-variant of the [[Bourne shell]]; it is a fast, small, [[POSIX]]-compatible [[Unix shell]] designed to replace the Bourne shell in later [[BSD]] distributions. Originally it did not feature line editing{{Clarify|date=March 2010}} or [[command history]] mechanisms, because Almquist felt that such should be moved into the [[Computer terminal|terminal]] [[Device driver|driver]]; however, current variants support it. Derivatives of ash are installed as the default shell (/bin/sh) on [[FreeBSD]], [[NetBSD]], [[DragonFly BSD]] and [[Minix]]. ash is also fairly popular in [[embedded Linux]] systems; its code was incorporated into the [[BusyBox]] catch-all executable often employed in this area. [[Debian]]'s version of ash is known as [[Debian Almquist shell|Debian Almquist Shell (dash)]]. Some [[Linux distribution]]s also use [[Debian_Almquist_shell|a derivative of ash]] as the default shell, although [[Bash (Unix shell)|Bash]] (Bourne Again Shell) is more popular. Debian and [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] [[Symbolic link|symlink]] /bin/sh to the dash shell for faster [[Shell script|script]] execution, but keeps Bash as the default login shell. The following is extracted from the ash package information from [[Slackware]]:
ash (Kenneth Almquist's ash shell)''
A lightweight (92K) Bourne compatible shell. Great for machines with low memory, but does not provide all the extras of shells like [[Bash_(Unix_shell)|bash]], [[tcsh]], and [[zsh]]. Runs most shell scripts compatible with the Bourne shell. Note that under Linux, most scripts seem to use at least some bash-specific syntax. The Slackware setup scripts are a notable exception, since ash is the shell used on the install disks. NetBSD and Ubuntu uses ash as its /bin/sh.
Ash has since been replaced on both [[Debian]] and [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]]. Dash became the replacement for ash in Debian and was expected to be the default /bin/sh for Debian Lenny.[http://release.debian.org/lenny/goals.txt Release goals for Debian Lenny][http://lists.debian.org/debian-devel-announce/2008/04/msg00002.html Release Update: architecture status, release goal status, BSPs] Dash became the default /bin/sh in [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] starting with the 6.10 release in October 2006.[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DashAsBinSh Dash as /bin/sh in Ubuntu 6.10] ==See also== * [[Comparison of computer shells]] * [[test (Unix)]] == References == {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{citation |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=53zaxy423xcC&pg=PA158&lpg=PA158&dq=Almquist+shell&source=bl&ots=T-VxLO5xbB&sig=qZMamuZrgyDmI5PPCOWKIVqBius&hl=en&ei=hAZkTs-fI4XZ0QHgiLSGCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAzg8#v=onepage&q=Almquist%20shell&f=false |title=Beginning Portable Shell Scripting: From Novice to Professional |author=Peter Seebach |publisher=Apress |year=2008 |isbn=1430210435 }} ==External links == *{{official|http://www.in-ulm.de/~mascheck/various/ash/}} {{Unix Shells}} {{compu-prog-stub}} {{unix-stub}} [[Category:Text-oriented programming languages]] [[Category:Scripting languages]] [[Category:Unix shells]] [[Category:Cross-platform software]] [[el:ÎÎ­Î»ÏÏÎ¿Ï Almquist]] [[fr:Almquist shell]] [[ja:Almquist Shell]] [[ru:Almquist shell]]
